content: How can I convert HTML entities to Unicode and vice versa using Python?

To convert HTML entities to Unicode and vice versa in Python, you can use the `html` module which provides convenient functions for these conversions. Here's how you can do it: ### Converting HTML Entities to Unicode You can use the `html.unescape()` function to convert HTML entities to Unicode characters. ```python import html # Example HTML string with entities html_string = "This is an example: <div>Hello, World!</div> & © 2023" # Convert HTML entities to Unicode unicode_string = html.unescape(html_string) print(unicode_string) ``` ### Converting Unicode to HTML Entities To convert Unicode characters to HTML entities, you can use the `html.escape()` function. However, `html.escape()` only converts certain characters like `<`, `>`, `&`, and `"`. If you need to convert other Unicode characters to their respective HTML entities, you might need to use a more manual approach or a library like `htmlentities`. ```python import html # Example Unicode string unicode_string = "
Hello, World!
& © 2023" # Convert Unicode to HTML entities html_string = html.escape(unicode_string) print(html_string) ``` For more comprehensive Unicode to named HTML entity conversion, you might have to use a custom mapping or an additional library, as Python's standard library does not include this functionality for all possible named entities. If you need to handle a broader range of entities, consider using third-party libraries like `htmlentitydefs` (Python 2) or `html5lib`, though these may require additional setup or manual mapping.
